title: Scala vs. Freight
content:
I'm looking to purchase an entire font family soon. But as you all know, it's an investment. I'm torn between Scala Sans and Freight Sans. Basically, I'm looking for a family that has a wide range of applications (from text to signage). Also, which one of these fonts do you think has the best companion serif design? (I'll purchase this family in the near future) Which one is the best value for the money? Your suggestions will be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance  
Ivan
author: Mister M

comments.content: Freight for sure.

I think you would be very pleased with either.

Value is essentially the same, though you can buy individual weights of [FF Scala](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617/http:/typophile.com/wiki/FF%20Scala), if that makes sense for your needs.

As for style, FF Scala is more distinctive so may not be as useful for a broad range of jobs.

Keep in mind that Freight is spaced very tightly so will need some extra care for text.
While you're at it you should check out TheSans it's also a good workhorse sans with individual weights available and also an expert collection. It's a bit more expensive tho.
I've been very happy with Freight Sans + Text.

As Freight is selling so well, I'd be interested in what your customers love about it Stephen, and why you went for it Mili. For example, isn't there a lot of competition for an old style serif with short ascenders? For humanist sans? Are people in love with the design? Is the completeness a key feature? Eg are people buying the all the variations?

I needed a combination of sans and serif that would work well together in a single word. After trying to pair various combinations I started to look for a not too expensive family with both. I liked Freight text's italic k and r and the clean shapes of the sans. In the end it's all subjective, I just liked the font. I might not have bought all varieties had that been an option, but now I'm happy it wasn't. Still looking for an project that would give me an excuse to buy the Micro.  
I didn't realise it was such a popular one when I bought it.

William - I think any family with [serif and sans companions](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617/http:/www.fontshop.com/virtual/newsletters/jun2006_b/) is appealing simply due to its versatility. As for Freight's popularity, these all factor in:

- The sans hits all the right notes for contemporary typography: large x-height, open forms, wide, nothing too quirky but more humanist than geometric.  
- [Darden's documentation and samples](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617/http:/www.joshuadarden.com/shop) lend it a lot of credibility.  
- The Micro weight is intriguing.

And here is Freight as featured in the [QBN Typecase](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/sets/72157594511485997/) and [_Font 004_](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617/http:/www.fontshop.com/features/fontmag/004/004_contents.cfm):

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617im_/http:/typophile.com/files/376074014_9e2c847691_o_4410.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617im_/http:/typophile.com/files/freight-in-font-magazine_3540.jpg)

Thanks, Stephen, Mili. I see that having a good sans with the serif is a real plus--and I think it's pretty difficult to pull off well, so hats off to Joshua Darden.

Stephen, what's interesting is that your rather complete list is pretty short. By the way I'm surprised you didn't include Scala & Scala sans in your 'pairs' list, as I think this was the first one so designed and very successful, no?
I think we omitted the most obvious family due to space considerations, but Scala is certainly our best selling suite.

Freight serif has size scalings.  
Scala has Seria as related.

\*\*

However, I'm not so sure about sans+serif families.  
No harm in foundries offering both, but that doesn't mean they should be bought and used as a team.  
I was just looking at a clipping from Hi-Fi magazine, 1964 (it came in an old vinyl album -- a nice bonus!):

Text: Times  
Subheads (for album titles under review); Garamond Italic  
Headlines: Bodoni Bold  
Section heads: Futura Bold, U&lc, slightly letterspaced

Piquant.

Perhaps for advanced typographers the pairings might be a little obvious--that's not to say they are bad--but for the layperson I think it is a wonderful way to introduce them to typography and the possibilities of going beyond Times and Helvetica.
Right Tiff, I should have said "doesn't _necessarily_ mean they should be bought and used as a team," which was the meaning I intended. Thanks for the clarification.
Anything to help. :^)

\> Scala is certainly our best selling suite.

This may soon be topped by FF Meta/Meta Serif. You heard it here first.

I do not have a license for Freight text, but I have used the sans & micro both quite regularly on several jobs and am very happy with both. The dark weights of the sans version are terrific for signage, just beautiful, and the face is mechanically very well-constructed as well.

Meta serif? Stephen, you never tell me anything.

[FontBook](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617/http:/typophile.com/wiki/FontBook) is not really an "FF" publication. It's published by FontShop International. FontFont is simply FontShop's foundry, a "house label" if you will. But I understand the confusion between the two brands.

Regardless, [FontFont.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617/http:/www.fontfont.com/), [FontShop.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617/http:/fontshop.com/) and [FontBook.com](http://web.archive.org/) will all lead you to the [FontBook page](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617/http:/www.fontshop.com/products/fontbook.cfm). As you're in Perth, you'll need to contact FS Australia for delivery.

Maybe the new serif version will help me get over my negativity? I second the call for a peek!!! Don't tease us!!!

Yeah, Stephen is a TypeTease!

I have Freight Text. My personal preferance is that a font (sans or otherwise) have an obviously true italic, which Freight Sans does not. Scala does. So does Parisine Plus and TheSans. The serif and sans have to be able to WORK together, not just LOOK like they're related.

There's nothing that isn't "true" about Freight Sans Italic. The forms may not be drastically different, but they are [optically corrected](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308211617/http:/www.marksimonson.com/article/128/fake-vs-true-italics) italic lettershapes not obliques and work quite well for emphasis without distracting.
